tagline: Disrupting Auth Flows and Naptime Schedules
mission_statement: At TamperTantrum Labs, our mission is to make application security accessible, human, and empowering. We partner with developers, open-source teams, and startups to identify vulnerabilities, implement real-world protections, build developer-friendly security tools, and create safer software; not just for the sake of the app, but for the safety of the people who use it.
vision: TamperTantrum Labs envisions a future where application security is no longer an afterthought, but a natural part of how great software gets built, shared, taught, and championed by empowered developers everywhere.
pitch: TamperTantrum Labs discovers vulnerabilities and builds tools to help devs and small teams secure their apps without the drama. We test, teach, build security tools, and tamper-proof your products, so you can ship them safely.

brand_story.full: I started TamperTantrum Labs out of pure frustration, not with cybersecurity itself, but with the wall I kept hitting when trying to break into the industry. I earned my certifications, completed a cybersecurity degree, competed in CTFs, contributed to open-source security projects, and networked like crazy, but still, the job market wouldn't budge. Months passed. I had the skills, but no job offers. So I stopped waiting for permission and decided to make my own way in. TamperTantrum Labs is my way of doing what I love: helping real developers and small teams secure their apps, their users, and their peace of mind. I work with solo devs, open source maintainers, and startups who care about security, even if they don't know where to start. I don't believe in fear-mongering, gatekeeping, or burying people in jargon. I believe in practical security: testing real threats, building real defenses, and empowering people to think and build with security in mind. Whether it's threat modeling, web and API testing, CI/CD hardening, or simply showing someone how their app could be broken, I'm here to help devs and small teams secure what they're building, and learn while doing it. Because security isn't just about protecting software. It's about protecting the people who use it.
